side-effects:
Side-effects see notes above and Diazepam, %s

doses:
By mouth, 2–3 mg the night before operation;
2–4 mg 1–2 hours before operation

with an equal volume of sodium chloride intravenous

before operation

By intramuscular injection, diluted as above,
50 micrograms/kg 60–90 minutes before operation

indications:
Indications short-term use in anxiety or insomnia (see section 4.1);
status epilepticus (section 4.8.2); peri-operative (section 15.1.4.1)
name: LORAZEPAM - ANXIOLYTICS
cautions:
Cautions see under Diazepam; short
acting; when given parenterally, facilities
for managing respiratory depression with mechanical ventilation must
be available
doses:
By mouth, anxiety, 1–4 mg daily in
divided doses; elderly (or debilitated)
half adult dose
Insomnia associated with anxiety, 1–2 mg at bedtime; child not recommended

By intramuscular or slow intravenous injection (into a large vein), acute
panic attacks, 25–30 micrograms/kg (usual range 1.5–2.5 mg), repeated
every 6 hours if necessary; child not
recommended

Only use intramuscular route when oral and
intravenous routes not possible
pregnancy:
Pregnancy 
(From Benzodiazepines: British National Formulary)
Pregnancy There is a risk of neonatal withdrawal symptoms when benzodiazepines are used during pregnancy. Avoid regular use and use only if there is a clear indication such as seizure control. High doses administered during late pregnancy or labour may cause neonatal hypothermia, hypotonia, and respiratory depression.
